notes.note:
Firefox 67 demonstrates improved performance thanks to a number of changes such as: 

- Lowering priority of `setTimeout` during page load
- Delayed component initialization until after start up
- Painting sooner during page load but less often
- Suspending unused tabs

Learn more about our approach to performance in 67 in the [Mozilla blog][1].


  [1]: https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2019/05/21/latest-firefox-release-is-faster-than-ever/

Users can block known cryptominers and fingerprinters in the Custom settings of their [Content Blocking preferences][1].


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/content-blocking

Keyboard accessibility has improved in the latest version of Firefox. Toolbar and toolbar overflow menu are both [fully keyboard accessible][1]: keyboard users can now access add-ons, the downloads panel, the overflow, Page actions and Firefox menus, and much more.


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/access-toolbar-functions-using-keyboard

[Private Browsing][1] sees both [usability and security improvements][2]: 

 - Save passwords in private browsing mode
 - Choose which extensions to exclude from private tabs

  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/extensions-private-browsing
  [2]: https://blog.mozilla.org/addons/2019/03/26/extensions-in-firefox-67/

A myriad of new features help make Firefox easier to use:

 - We’ve added a [toolbar menu][1] for your Firefox Account to provide more transparency for when you are synced, sharing data across devices and with Firefox. Personalize the appearance of the menu with your own avatar
 - Tabs can now be [pinned][2] from the Page Actions menu in the address bar
 - Firefox will highlight useful features (like Pin Tabs) when users are most likely to benefit from them.
 - Easier access to your list of saved logins from the [main menu and login autocomplete][3]. Learn about all the ways you can [manage your passwords][4] in Firefox. 
 - The Import Data from Another Browser feature is now also available from the File menu
 - Users will be able to run different Firefox installs [side by side by default][5] so that you can [run the beta and release versions simultaneously][6]


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/how-do-i-know-status-my-sync
  [2]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/pinned-tabs-keep-favorite-websites-open
  [3]: https://matthew.noorenberghe.com/blog/2019/05/password-manager-improvements-firefox-67
  [4]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-and-import
  [5]: https://blog.nightly.mozilla.org/2019/01/14/moving-to-a-profile-per-install-architecture/
  [6]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/dedicated-profiles-firefox-installation
Firefox will now protect you against running older versions of the browser which can lead to data corruption and stability issues
Firefox is upgrading to the newer, higher performance, AV1 decoder known as ‘dav1d’

WebRender is [gradually enabled][1] by default on Windows 10 desktops with NVIDIA graphics cards


  [1]: https://mozillagfx.wordpress.com/2019/05/21/graphics-team-ships-webrender-mvp/
Mozilla’s highest performing JavaScript compiler now supports ARM64 Windows devices.

[Enable FIDO U2F API][1], and permit registrations for Google Accounts


  [1]: https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2019/04/04/shipping-fido-u2f-api-support-in-firefox/

Some users will see experiments with an [improved Pocket experience][1] in Firefox Home with different layouts and more topical content. 


  [1]: https://help.getpocket.com/article/1149-firefox-home-layout-tests-faq
Firefox no longer supports handling webcal: links with 30boxes.com
*Change to extensions in Private Windows:*  Any new extensions you add to the browser won’t work in Private Windows unless you allow this in the settings.

Users will [no longer be able to upload and share screenshots][1] through the Firefox Screenshots server. Users who want to keep existing screenshots need to [export][2] them before the server shuts down in the coming months.


  [1]: https://blog.mozilla.org/futurereleases/2019/01/24/clarifying-the-future-of-firefox-screenshots/
  [2]: https://screenshots.firefox.com/export
Included Twemoji Mozilla font updated to support Emoji 11.0 🥳
Font and date adjustments to accommodate the new Reiwa era in Japan
The DevTools Changes panel now supports copying modified CSS. You can either copy the full changes or individual changed rules.
CSS Viewport-compat - Firefox for Android's mobile viewport behavior is now aligned with other browsers, resolving known compatibility issues with websites.
JavaScript module imports - Firefox now supports dynamic module imports.

New streamlined worker debugging in the [JavaScript Debugger][1] with the new Threads panel.


  [1]: https://hacks.mozilla.org/2019/05/faster-smarter-javascript-debugging-in-firefox/
New inline breakpoints provided by the JavaScript Debugger give a much higher fidelity and reliability for pausing in specific locations within a line of code.

Various [security fixes][1]


  [1]: https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/advisories/mfsa2019-13/

Windows users with Direct2D disabled or WebRender enabled may see color fringing on text on some screens ([bug 1553910][1]).


  [1]: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1553910

TinyMCE versions 3.4.4 and earlier are not compatible with Firefox 67 and later, because they have a Firefox-specific codepath that assumes non-standard behavior and that behavior was removed.  This can be addressed by updating to TinyMCE 3.4.5 or later, or by modifying the `setupIframe()` function in `tiny_mce.js` to have the `d.open()` call right before the big conditional block that adds a `DOMContentLoader` event listener, not right after that block ([bug 1554014][1]).


  [1]: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1554014

For some Firefox users who have antivirus programs installed, the master password dialog appears more than once. Information for [a workaround fix is on support.mozilla.org][1]. 


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/firefox-keeps-asking-me-master-password

system_requirements:
## Windows

### Operating Systems (32-bit and 64-bit)
 - Windows 7
 - Windows 8
 - Windows 10

### Recommended Hardware
-  Pentium 4 or newer processor that supports SSE2
-  512MB of RAM / 2GB of RAM for the 64-bit version
-  200MB of hard drive space

---

## Mac

### Operating Systems
- macOS 10.9
- macOS 10.10
- macOS 10.11
- macOS 10.12
- macOS 10.13
- macOS 10.14

### Recommended Hardware
- Macintosh computer with an Intel x86 processor
- 512 MB of RAM
- 200 MB hard drive space

---

## GNU/Linux

### Software Requirements

*Please note that GNU/Linux distributors may provide packages for your distribution which have different requirements.*

- Firefox will not run at all without the following libraries or packages:
    - GTK+ 3.4 or higher
    - GLib 2.22 or higher
    - Pango 1.22 or higher
    - X.Org 1.0 or higher (1.7 or higher is recommended)
    - libstdc++ 4.6.1 or higher
- For optimal functionality, we recommend the following libraries or packages:
    - NetworkManager 0.7 or higher
    - DBus 1.0 or higher
    - GNOME 2.16 or higher
    - PulseAudio
text:
We'd like to extend a special thank you to all of the [new Mozillians][1] who contributed to this release of Firefox!


  [1]: https://blog.mozilla.org/community/2019/04/30/firefox-67-new-contributors/
title: Firefox 67.0 Release
